method: First, calculate charge: Q = I × t = 1.50 A × (30.0 × 60) s = 2700 C. Then find moles of electrons: n(e-) = Q / F = 2700 / 96500 = 0.02798 mol. From the half-equation Cu2+ + 2e- → Cu, each mole of Cu requires 2 moles of electrons, so n(Cu) = 0.02798 / 2 = 0.01399 mol. Finally, mass of Cu = n × Mr = 0.01399 × 63.55 = 0.889 g.
checks: The stoichiometry of the half-equation correctly shows 2 electrons are required per Cu atom deposited, halving the moles of copper compared to moles of electrons.
